title: 1220-C
statement: C. Substring Game in the Lessontime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 mebibytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputMike and Ann are sitting in the classroom. The lesson is boring, so they decided to play an interesting game. Fortunately, all they need to play this game is a string $$$s$$$ and a number $$$k$$$ ($$$0 \\le k < |s|$$$).At the beginning of the game, players are given a substring of $$$s$$$ with left border $$$l$$$ and right border $$$r$$$, both equal to $$$k$$$ (i.e. initially $$$l=r=k$$$). Then players start to make moves one by one, according to the following rules:A player chooses $$$l^{\\prime}$$$ and $$$r^{\\prime}$$$ so that $$$l^{\\prime} \\le l$$$, $$$r^{\\prime} \\ge r$$$ and $$$s[l^{\\prime}, r^{\\prime}]$$$ is lexicographically less than $$$s[l, r]$$$. Then the player changes $$$l$$$ and $$$r$$$ in this way: $$$l := l^{\\prime}$$$, $$$r := r^{\\prime}$$$.Ann moves first.The player, that can't make a move loses.Recall that a substring $$$s[l, r]$$$ ($$$l \\le r$$$) of a string $$$s$$$ is a continuous segment of letters from s that starts at position $$$l$$$ and ends at position $$$r$$$. For example, "ehn" is a substring ($$$s[3, 5]$$$) of "aaaehnsvz" and "ahz" is not.Mike and Ann were playing so enthusiastically that they did not notice the teacher approached them. Surprisingly, the teacher didn't scold them, instead of that he said, that he can figure out the winner of the game before it starts, even if he knows only $$$s$$$ and $$$k$$$.Unfortunately, Mike and Ann are not so keen in the game theory, so they ask you to write a program, that takes $$$s$$$ and determines the winner for all possible $$$k$$$.InputThe first line of the input contains a single string $$$s$$$ ($$$1 \\leq |s| \\leq 5 \\cdot 10^5$$$) consisting of lowercase English letters.OutputPrint $$$|s|$$$ lines.In the line $$$i$$$ write the name of the winner (printMikeorAnn) in the game with string $$$s$$$ and $$$k = i$$$, if both play optimallyExamplesInputabbaOutputMike Ann Ann MikeInputcbaOutputMike Mike Mike

processed.result:
Given a string $s$ of length $n$, determine the winner of a game played as follows:

Two players take turns selecting a substring of $s$ with a starting and ending index.  The substring chosen must be lexicographically smaller than the previous substring. The player who cannot make a valid move loses.

The game starts with the substring $s[k, k]$ where $k$ is an integer between 0 and $n-1$.  

For each possible value of $k$ (from 0 to $n-1$), determine which player (Player 1 or Player 2) will win if both players play optimally.
Given a string, determine who wins a game where two players take turns selecting a smaller substring from the string. The player who can no longer make a smaller selection loses.
